Element pattern
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
The top level (typically root) element which defines a knitting pattern.
Diagram
Properties
content: complex
Model directives{0,1} , general-information , supplies , directions
Children directions, directives, general-information, supplies
Instance
 
<pattern xml:lang="" version="">
  <directives type="">{0,1}</directives>
  <general-information xml:lang="">{1,1}</general-information>
  <supplies>{1,1}</supplies>
  <directions>{1,1}</directions>
</pattern>
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
version xsd:string required 
The major / minor version of the KnitML Specification schema. Example:
0.6. Used for backward compatibility so that software can process older schemas and make
adjustments if necessary.
xml:lang union of(xs:language, restriction of xs:string) optional 
Attempting to install the relevant ISO 2- and 3-letter
         codes as the enumerated possible values is probably never
         going to be a realistic possibility.  See
         RFC 3066 at http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt and the IANA registry
         at http://www.iana.org/assignments/lang-tag-apps.htm for
         further information.

         The union allows for the 'un-declaration' of xml:lang with
         the empty string.
Source
 
<xsd:element name="pattern">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>The top level (typically root) element which defines a knitting pattern.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:complexType>
    <xsd:sequence>
      <xsd:element name="directives" type="DirectivesType" minOccurs="0"/>
      <xsd:element name="general-information" type="GeneralInformationType"/>
      <xsd:element name="supplies" type="SuppliesType"/>
      <xsd:element name="directions" type="DirectionsType"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:attribute ref="xml:lang" use="optional">
      <xsd:annotation>
        <xsd:documentation>The ISO-639 language code that the pattern is written in. If the pattern is fully internationalized, this attribute should not be specified.</xsd:documentation>
      </xsd:annotation>
    </xsd:attribute>
    <xsd:attribute name="version" type="xsd:string" use="required">
      <xsd:annotation>
        <xsd:documentation>The major / minor version of the KnitML Specification schema. Example: 0.6. Used for backward compatibility so that software can process older schemas and make adjustments if necessary.</xsd:documentation>
      </xsd:annotation>
    </xsd:attribute>
  </xsd:complexType>
</xsd:element>

Element InstructionDefinitionsType / instruction
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type InstructionType
Properties
content: complex
Model (row+) | for-each-row-in-instruction
Children for-each-row-in-instruction, row
Instance
 
<instruction id="" label="" message-key="" row-count="" shape="">
  <row assign-row-number="" inform-side="" long="false" number="" reset-row-count="" short="false" side="" subsequent="" type="" yarn-ref="">{1,unbounded}</row>
  <for-each-row-in-instruction ref="">{1,1}</for-each-row-in-instruction>
</instruction>
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
id id-type required
label xsd:string optional
message-key message-key-type optional
row-count xsd:short optional 
States the expected number of rows for this instruction. This is only
mandatory if the rows contained within this instruction use the "subsequent" attribute to
extend their definition to even or odd rows. It can be used without the "subsequent"
attribute to validate expectations.
shape restriction of xsd:string optional 
Documents the shape of the work, i.e. whether it is knit flat or in the
  round. If the instruction appears in the header (under an
  <instruction-definition> element) then this attribute must be
specified.
Source
 
<xsd:element name="instruction" type="InstructionType"/>
Element InstructionType / row
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type RowType
Properties
content: complex
maxOccurs: unbounded
Model information{0,1} , (bind-off | bind-off-all | knit | purl | work-even | decrease | double-decrease | increase | increase-into-next-stitch | cross-stitches | slip | slip-to-stitch-holder | from-stitch-holder | pass-previous-stitch-over | no-stitch | turn | place-marker | inline-cast-on | inline-pick-up-stitches | designate-end-of-row | remove-marker | inline-instruction-ref | apply-next-row | repeat | using-needle | inline-instruction) , followup-information{0,1}
Children apply-next-row, bind-off, bind-off-all, cross-stitches, decrease, designate-end-of-row, double-decrease, followup-information, from-stitch-holder, increase, increase-into-next-stitch, information, inline-cast-on, inline-instruction, inline-instruction-ref, inline-pick-up-stitches, knit, no-stitch, pass-previous-stitch-over, place-marker, purl, remove-marker, repeat, slip, slip-to-stitch-holder, turn, using-needle, work-even
Instance
 
<row assign-row-number="" inform-side="" long="false" number="" reset-row-count="" short="false" side="" subsequent="" type="" yarn-ref="">
  <information>{0,1}</information>
  <followup-information>{0,1}</followup-information>
</row>
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
assign-row-number xsd:boolean optional 
Informs a pre-processor that it should assign a row number to the 'row'
attribute if none was provided.
inform-side xsd:boolean optional 
Indicates that a pre-processor should calculate the current knitting side
and add this value to the 'side' attribute. If the 'side' attribute has already been
provided, this has no effect.
long xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is long if the stitch operations it defines run into the next row.
number list of xsd:short optional 
The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number,
it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any
existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row
numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form
of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction
element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should
assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number
attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).
reset-row-count reset-row-count-type optional
short xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is short if there will be unworked stitches after this row's
operations are executed. Unworked stitches may occur at either the beginning or the end of
the row. A row that is short but is not marked that way is not valid.
side restriction of xsd:string optional 
The side of the work that is facing the knitter when the row begins.
Indicates that a rendering program should display this value. This value can be calculated
by a pre-processor, or it can be provided. If it is provided and validation is performed,
it serves as an assertion.
subsequent restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates whether this row is to be repeated for all following even
or odd rows within this instruction. Only valid when defined within an instruction and
that instruction has its "row-count" attribute defined. An unspecified value is equivalent
to "none", meaning that this row element only defines the row numbers specified by the
"number" attribute.
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
The current shape of knitting, either 'flat' or 'round.' Specifying this
attribute informs the renderer to use the appropriate row header for this shape. If this
attribute is not provided, a pre-processor should calculate this value. If this attribute
is provided and validation is performed, it serves as an assertion.
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source

Element atomicInlineOperations / decrease
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type DecreaseType
Properties
content: complex
default: 1
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates the type of decrease to perform. Note that the decrease names are defined assuming stitch mounts using Western knitting techniques.
Recognized decreases are:
ssk: slip-slip-knit (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, knit the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
k2tog: knit 2 together (knit 2 stitches together)
ssp: slip-slip-purl (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, purl the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
p2tog: purl 2 together (purl 2 stitches together)
skp: slip, knit, psso (slip 1 purlwise, knit 1, pass slipped stitch over knitted stitch)
k2tog-tbl: knit 2 together through their trailing loop
p2tog-tbl: purl 2 together through their trailing loop
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:element name="decrease" type="DecreaseType" default="1"/>
Element atomicInlineOperations / double-decrease
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type DoubleDecreaseType
Properties
content: complex
default: 1
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates the type of double decrease to perform.
Recognized double decreases are:
cdd:        center double decrease (slip 2 sts together knitwise, k, pass slipped sts over)
sk2p:       slip 1 st knitwise, k2tog, pass slipped stitch over
k3tog:      knit 3 together
p3tog:      purl 3 together
sssk:       slip 3 stitches knitwise, return to working needle, then knit the stitches together
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:element name="double-decrease" type="DoubleDecreaseType" default="1"/>
Element atomicInlineOperations / increase
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type IncreaseType
Properties
content: complex
default: 1
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates the type of increase to perform.
Recognized increases are:
m1: generic knit increase (implied if type is not specified)
m1p: generic purled increase
m1a: make 1 away (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing away)
m1t: make 1 towards (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing towards)
m1l: make one left (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1r: make one right (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1lp: make one left purled (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, purl through trailing loop)
m1rp: make one right purled (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, purl through trailing loop)
kll: knit left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, knit through trailing loop)
krl: knit right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, knit through leading loop)
pll: purl left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, purl through trailing loop)
prl: purl right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, purl through leading loop)
kfb: knit front and back (knit through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
pfb: purl front and back (purl through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
moss: knit through leading loop, then purl through leading loop of same st
decorative: knit into strand between sts
yo: bring working yarn in front and wrap it from bottom to top around the needle
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source

<xsd:element name="cross-stitches" type="CrossStitchesType"/>
Element atomicInlineOperations / slip
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type SlipType
Properties
content: complex
default: 1
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
direction restriction of xsd:string forward optional 
A value of forward indicates that the stitch(es) is/are to be slipped
as if working forwards (from needle holding stitches to work to needle holding
stitches just worked). A value of reverse indicates that the stitch(es) are to be
slipped as if working in reverse (from needle holding stitches just worked to needle
holding stitches to work).
type restriction of xsd:string purlwise optional 
Designates if the stitch is slipped as if to knit or as if to purl.
Default is purlwise.
yarn-position restriction of xsd:string back optional 
Where the yarn is held when the stitches are slipped. Default is
'back', which means that the yarn is to the back of the work.
Source

id id-type optional
until restriction of xsd:string required 
Specifies the terminating condition of this repeat. Values are:
end: repeat to the end (of the block inline operation)
before end: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is end
before gap: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a gap
before marker: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a marker
marker: repeat until a marker is encountered
times: a declared number of times (total, not additional)
value xsd:short optional 
The value which complements the evaluation of the 'until'
expression.
Source
 
<xsd:element name="repeat" type="RepeatType"/>

Element atomicInlineOperations / turn
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type TurnType
Properties
content: complex
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
inform-unworked-stitches xsd:boolean optional 
Indicates that a pre-processor should calculate the number of stitches
that haven't been worked in the row at the time of turning and add this value as the
'stitches-left' attribute. If the 'stitches-left' attribute has already been provided,
this has no effect.
stitches-left xsd:short optional 
The number of stitches left to work in the row when the work is turned.
Indicates that a rendering program should display this value. This value can be calculated
by a pre-processor, or it can be provided. If it is provided and validation is performed,
this number serves as an assertion.
Source

Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
silent xsd:boolean optional 
When set to true, indicates that the operation should not be rendered but
is merely a directive to a computer program. If a cast-on element immediately follows a
this element and 'silent' is set to true, the intent is that these needles will be used
for the cast on, and a renderer may choose to mention which needles to cast onto as part
of rendering the cast on operation (rather than this one).

Element DirectionsType / instruction
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type InstructionType
Properties
content: complex
Model (row+) | for-each-row-in-instruction
Children for-each-row-in-instruction, row
Instance
 
<instruction id="" label="" message-key="" row-count="" shape="">
  <row assign-row-number="" inform-side="" long="false" number="" reset-row-count="" short="false" side="" subsequent="" type="" yarn-ref="">{1,unbounded}</row>
  <for-each-row-in-instruction ref="">{1,1}</for-each-row-in-instruction>
</instruction>
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
id id-type required
label xsd:string optional
message-key message-key-type optional
row-count xsd:short optional 
States the expected number of rows for this instruction. This is only
mandatory if the rows contained within this instruction use the "subsequent" attribute to
extend their definition to even or odd rows. It can be used without the "subsequent"
attribute to validate expectations.
shape restriction of xsd:string optional 
Documents the shape of the work, i.e. whether it is knit flat or in the
  round. If the instruction appears in the header (under an
  <instruction-definition> element) then this attribute must be
specified.
Source

<xsd:element name="instruction-ref" type="InstructionRefType"/>
Element DirectionsType / row
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Diagram
Type RowType
Properties
content: complex
Model information{0,1} , (bind-off | bind-off-all | knit | purl | work-even | decrease | double-decrease | increase | increase-into-next-stitch | cross-stitches | slip | slip-to-stitch-holder | from-stitch-holder | pass-previous-stitch-over | no-stitch | turn | place-marker | inline-cast-on | inline-pick-up-stitches | designate-end-of-row | remove-marker | inline-instruction-ref | apply-next-row | repeat | using-needle | inline-instruction) , followup-information{0,1}
Children apply-next-row, bind-off, bind-off-all, cross-stitches, decrease, designate-end-of-row, double-decrease, followup-information, from-stitch-holder, increase, increase-into-next-stitch, information, inline-cast-on, inline-instruction, inline-instruction-ref, inline-pick-up-stitches, knit, no-stitch, pass-previous-stitch-over, place-marker, purl, remove-marker, repeat, slip, slip-to-stitch-holder, turn, using-needle, work-even
Instance
 
<row assign-row-number="" inform-side="" long="false" number="" reset-row-count="" short="false" side="" subsequent="" type="" yarn-ref="">
  <information>{0,1}</information>
  <followup-information>{0,1}</followup-information>
</row>
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
assign-row-number xsd:boolean optional 
Informs a pre-processor that it should assign a row number to the 'row'
attribute if none was provided.
inform-side xsd:boolean optional 
Indicates that a pre-processor should calculate the current knitting side
and add this value to the 'side' attribute. If the 'side' attribute has already been
provided, this has no effect.
long xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is long if the stitch operations it defines run into the next row.
number list of xsd:short optional 
The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number,
it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any
existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row
numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form
of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction
element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should
assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number
attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).
reset-row-count reset-row-count-type optional
short xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is short if there will be unworked stitches after this row's
operations are executed. Unworked stitches may occur at either the beginning or the end of
the row. A row that is short but is not marked that way is not valid.
side restriction of xsd:string optional 
The side of the work that is facing the knitter when the row begins.
Indicates that a rendering program should display this value. This value can be calculated
by a pre-processor, or it can be provided. If it is provided and validation is performed,
it serves as an assertion.
subsequent restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates whether this row is to be repeated for all following even
or odd rows within this instruction. Only valid when defined within an instruction and
that instruction has its "row-count" attribute defined. An unspecified value is equivalent
to "none", meaning that this row element only defines the row numbers specified by the
"number" attribute.
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
The current shape of knitting, either 'flat' or 'round.' Specifying this
attribute informs the renderer to use the appropriate row header for this shape. If this
attribute is not provided, a pre-processor should calculate this value. If this attribute
is provided and validation is performed, it serves as an assertion.
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:element name="row" type="RowType"/>

Type SectionType

content: complex

Complex Type InstructionType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
A referenceable set of rows. The rows may be specified explicitly, or they
may be derived by applying the logic in the for-each-row-in-instruction element across
another referenced instruction. Instruction elements are block operations, since they are
defined outside of a single row.
Diagram
Used by
Elements DirectionsType/instruction, InstructionDefinitionsType/instruction, InstructionGroupType/instruction, SectionType/instruction
Model (row+) | for-each-row-in-instruction
Children for-each-row-in-instruction, row
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
id id-type required
label xsd:string optional
message-key message-key-type optional
row-count xsd:short optional 
States the expected number of rows for this instruction. This is only
mandatory if the rows contained within this instruction use the "subsequent" attribute to
extend their definition to even or odd rows. It can be used without the "subsequent"
attribute to validate expectations.
shape restriction of xsd:string optional 
Documents the shape of the work, i.e. whether it is knit flat or in the
  round. If the instruction appears in the header (under an
  <instruction-definition> element) then this attribute must be
specified.
Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="InstructionType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>A referenceable set of rows. The rows may be specified explicitly, or they may be derived by applying the logic in the for-each-row-in-instruction element across another referenced instruction. Instruction elements are block operations, since they are defined outside of a single row.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:choice>
    <xsd:sequence>
      <xsd:element name="row" type="RowType" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:element name="for-each-row-in-instruction" type="ForEachRowInInstructionType"/>
  </xsd:choice>
  <xsd:attribute name="id" type="id-type" use="required"/>
  <xsd:attribute name="shape">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>Documents the shape of the work, i.e. whether it is knit flat or in the round. If the instruction appears in the header (under an <instruction-definition> element) then this attribute must be specified.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:simpleType>
      <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
        <xsd:enumeration value="flat"/>
        <xsd:enumeration value="round"/>
      </xsd:restriction>
    </xsd:simpleType>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="row-count" type="xsd:short">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>States the expected number of rows for this instruction. This is only mandatory if the rows contained within this instruction use the "subsequent" attribute to extend their definition to even or odd rows. It can be used without the "subsequent" attribute to validate expectations.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attributeGroup ref="labelAttrs"/>
</xsd:complexType>
Complex Type RowType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
A row (or round) of knitting. Processing through a row's child elements
works all stitches on the current needles sequentially. The end of the row is reached when
the last stitch on the needles for this row has been worked. The last operation in this row
must put the knitting at the end of the row, unless the 'short' attribute has been set to
true.
Diagram
Used by
Elements DirectionsType/row, InstructionGroupType/row, InstructionType/row, SectionType/row
Model information{0,1} , (bind-off | bind-off-all | knit | purl | work-even | decrease | double-decrease | increase | increase-into-next-stitch | cross-stitches | slip | slip-to-stitch-holder | from-stitch-holder | pass-previous-stitch-over | no-stitch | turn | place-marker | inline-cast-on | inline-pick-up-stitches | designate-end-of-row | remove-marker | inline-instruction-ref | apply-next-row | repeat | using-needle | inline-instruction) , followup-information{0,1}
Children apply-next-row, bind-off, bind-off-all, cross-stitches, decrease, designate-end-of-row, double-decrease, followup-information, from-stitch-holder, increase, increase-into-next-stitch, information, inline-cast-on, inline-instruction, inline-instruction-ref, inline-pick-up-stitches, knit, no-stitch, pass-previous-stitch-over, place-marker, purl, remove-marker, repeat, slip, slip-to-stitch-holder, turn, using-needle, work-even
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
assign-row-number xsd:boolean optional 
Informs a pre-processor that it should assign a row number to the 'row'
attribute if none was provided.
inform-side xsd:boolean optional 
Indicates that a pre-processor should calculate the current knitting side
and add this value to the 'side' attribute. If the 'side' attribute has already been
provided, this has no effect.
long xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is long if the stitch operations it defines run into the next row.
number list of xsd:short optional 
The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number,
it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any
existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row
numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form
of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction
element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should
assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number
attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).
reset-row-count reset-row-count-type optional
short xsd:boolean false optional 
A row is short if there will be unworked stitches after this row's
operations are executed. Unworked stitches may occur at either the beginning or the end of
the row. A row that is short but is not marked that way is not valid.
side restriction of xsd:string optional 
The side of the work that is facing the knitter when the row begins.
Indicates that a rendering program should display this value. This value can be calculated
by a pre-processor, or it can be provided. If it is provided and validation is performed,
it serves as an assertion.
subsequent restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates whether this row is to be repeated for all following even
or odd rows within this instruction. Only valid when defined within an instruction and
that instruction has its "row-count" attribute defined. An unspecified value is equivalent
to "none", meaning that this row element only defines the row numbers specified by the
"number" attribute.
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
The current shape of knitting, either 'flat' or 'round.' Specifying this
attribute informs the renderer to use the appropriate row header for this shape. If this
attribute is not provided, a pre-processor should calculate this value. If this attribute
is provided and validation is performed, it serves as an assertion.
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="RowType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>A row (or round) of knitting. Processing through a row's child elements works all stitches on the current needles sequentially. The end of the row is reached when the last stitch on the needles for this row has been worked. The last operation in this row must put the knitting at the end of the row, unless the 'short' attribute has been set to true.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:sequence>

      </xsd:annotation>
    </xsd:element>
  </xsd:sequence>
  <xsd:attribute name="yarn-ref" type="yarn-ref-type"/>
  <xsd:attribute name="inform-side" type="xsd:boolean">
    <xsd:annotation>

    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>

    </xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:simpleType>
      <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
        <xsd:enumeration value="right"/>
        <xsd:enumeration value="wrong"/>
      </xsd:restriction>
    </xsd:simpleType>
  </xsd:attribute>

    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>A row is short if there will be unworked stitches after this row's operations are executed. Unworked stitches may occur at either the beginning or the end of the row. A row that is short but is not marked that way is not valid.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="long" type="xsd:boolean" default="false">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>A row is long if the stitch operations it defines run into the next row.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="assign-row-number" type="xsd:boolean">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>Informs a pre-processor that it should assign a row number to the 'row' attribute if none was provided.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="reset-row-count" type="reset-row-count-type"/>
  <xsd:attribute name="number">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number, it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:simpleType>
      <xsd:list itemType="xsd:short"/>
    </xsd:simpleType>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="subsequent">
    <xsd:annotation>

Only valid when defined within an instruction and that instruction has its "row-count" attribute defined. An unspecified value is equivalent to "none", meaning that this row element only defines the row numbers specified by the "number" attribute.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:simpleType>
      <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
        <xsd:enumeration value="even"/>
        <xsd:enumeration value="odd"/>
        <xsd:enumeration value="none"/>

    </xsd:simpleType>
  </xsd:attribute>

    </xsd:annotation>

      <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">

Complex Type KnitType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
The knit operation is defined as inserting the right-hand needle from left
to right into the next stitch. The yarn is behind the stitch for this operation, and the
stitch is worked through either the leading or the trailing loop.
Diagram
Type extension of xsd:short
Used by
Elements IncreaseIntoNextStitchType/knit, atomicInlineOperations/knit
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
loop-to-work restriction of xsd:string optional
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="KnitType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>The knit operation is defined as inserting the right-hand needle from left to right into the next stitch. The yarn is behind the stitch for this operation, and the stitch is worked through either the leading or the trailing loop.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:simpleContent>
    <xsd:extension base="xsd:short">
      <xsd:attribute name="yarn-ref" type="yarn-ref-type"/>
      <xsd:attribute name="loop-to-work">
        <xsd:simpleType>
          <xsd:annotation>
            <xsd:documentation>
              <![CDATA[
                leading: the side of the loop which is closest to the right-hand needle
                trailing: the side of the loop which is farthest from the right-hand needle
                ]]>
            </xsd:documentation>
          </xsd:annotation>
          <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
            <xsd:enumeration value="leading"/>
            <xsd:enumeration value="trailing"/>
          </xsd:restriction>
        </xsd:simpleType>
      </xsd:attribute>
    </xsd:extension>
  </xsd:simpleContent>
</xsd:complexType>

Complex Type WorkEvenType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
The work-even operation is defined as working the current stich(es) in the
  same manner as they were worked in the row below. If the stitch below was knit, then this is
  equivalent to a knit operation. If it was purled, it is equivalent to a purl
operation.

Complex Type DecreaseType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Represents a single decrease in the pattern. The content of this element
can indicate to repeat this decrease the specified number of times. See the various
enumeration values for the 'type' attribute below for more information describing each
decrease type.
Diagram
Type extension of xsd:short
Used by
Element atomicInlineOperations/decrease
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates the type of decrease to perform. Note that the decrease names are defined assuming stitch mounts using Western knitting techniques.
Recognized decreases are:
ssk: slip-slip-knit (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, knit the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
k2tog: knit 2 together (knit 2 stitches together)
ssp: slip-slip-purl (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, purl the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
p2tog: purl 2 together (purl 2 stitches together)
skp: slip, knit, psso (slip 1 purlwise, knit 1, pass slipped stitch over knitted stitch)
k2tog-tbl: knit 2 together through their trailing loop
p2tog-tbl: purl 2 together through their trailing loop
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source

Complex Type IncreaseType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Represents an increase in the pattern. The content of this element can
indicate to repeat this increase the specified number of times. See the various enumeration
values for the 'type' attribute below for more information describing each type of increase
decrease.
Diagram
Type extension of xsd:short
Used by
Element atomicInlineOperations/increase
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
Indicates the type of increase to perform.
Recognized increases are:
m1: generic knit increase (implied if type is not specified)
m1p: generic purled increase
m1a: make 1 away (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing away)
m1t: make 1 towards (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing towards)
m1l: make one left (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1r: make one right (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1lp: make one left purled (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, purl through trailing loop)
m1rp: make one right purled (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, purl through trailing loop)
kll: knit left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, knit through trailing loop)
krl: knit right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, knit through leading loop)
pll: purl left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, purl through trailing loop)
prl: purl right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, purl through leading loop)
kfb: knit front and back (knit through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
pfb: purl front and back (purl through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
moss: knit through leading loop, then purl through leading loop of same st
decorative: knit into strand between sts
yo: bring working yarn in front and wrap it from bottom to top around the needle
yarn-ref yarn-ref-type optional
Source

Complex Type CrossStitchesType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Starting with the next active stitch, cross the number of stitches
specified by the 'first' attribute in front of or behind (specified by the 'type' attribute)
the number of stitches specified by the 'next' attribute. Also known as a "cable crossing"
or "twisting stitches." The next stitch to be worked is the same stitch that was to be
worked before this operation began. In other words, no stitches are actually worked with an
active yarn. In order to specify a "full" cable manuever, a subsequent operation (or
several) would have to work 'first' + 'next' stitches.
Diagram
Used by
Element atomicInlineOperations/cross-stitches
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
first xsd:short optional 
The stitches to cross over / under.
next xsd:short optional 
The stitches to be crossed over / under by the stitches specified by
'first'.
type restriction of xsd:string optional 
The method by which the stiches are crossed. May be 'front' or
'back'.
Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="CrossStitchesType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>Starting with the next active stitch, cross the number of stitches specified by the 'first' attribute in front of or behind (specified by the 'type' attribute) the number of stitches specified by the 'next' attribute. Also known as a "cable crossing" or "twisting stitches." The next stitch to be worked is the same stitch that was to be worked before this operation began. In other words, no stitches are actually worked with an active yarn. In order to specify a "full" cable manuever, a subsequent operation (or several) would have to work 'first' + 'next' stitches.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:attribute name="first" type="xsd:short">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>The stitches to cross over / under.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="type">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>The method by which the stiches are crossed. May be 'front' or 'back'.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:simpleType>
      <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
        <xsd:enumeration value="front"/>
        <xsd:enumeration value="back"/>
      </xsd:restriction>
    </xsd:simpleType>
  </xsd:attribute>
  <xsd:attribute name="next" type="xsd:short">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>The stitches to be crossed over / under by the stitches specified by 'first'.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
</xsd:complexType>
Complex Type SlipType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Represents moving a series of stitches from the left to the right needle
without knitting them.
Diagram
Type extension of xsd:short
Used by
Element atomicInlineOperations/slip
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
direction restriction of xsd:string forward optional 
A value of forward indicates that the stitch(es) is/are to be slipped
as if working forwards (from needle holding stitches to work to needle holding
stitches just worked). A value of reverse indicates that the stitch(es) are to be
slipped as if working in reverse (from needle holding stitches just worked to needle
holding stitches to work).
type restriction of xsd:string purlwise optional 
Designates if the stitch is slipped as if to knit or as if to purl.
Default is purlwise.
yarn-position restriction of xsd:string back optional 
Where the yarn is held when the stitches are slipped. Default is
'back', which means that the yarn is to the back of the work.

Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern

Repeat the child elements (inline operations) as long as the 'until'

QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
id id-type optional
until restriction of xsd:string required 
Specifies the terminating condition of this repeat. Values are:
end: repeat to the end (of the block inline operation)
before end: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is end
before gap: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a gap
before marker: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a marker
marker: repeat until a marker is encountered
times: a declared number of times (total, not additional)
value xsd:short optional 
The value which complements the evaluation of the 'until'
expression.
Source

Complex Type UsingNeedleType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Scope the number of active stitches to the specified needle for the child
elements. This means, for instance, that a repeat to end operation that falls within a
using-needle element will only take the work to the end of the needle, not to the end of the
row (although the last using-needle operation should).
Diagram

Complex Type ApplyNextRowType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Perform the operations specified in the next row of the referenced
instruction. As an example, the first time this element is applied to an 8-row instruction,
row 1 would be applied. The next time, row 2 would be applied. In other words, a global
instance of the instruction is created, and each application of this element aplies the next
row in that instruction.
Diagram
Used by
Element atomicInlineOperations/apply-next-row
Attributes

instruction-ref idref-type optional

As an example, the first time this element is applied to an 8-row instruction, row 1 would be applied. The next time, row 2 would be applied. In other words, a global instance of the instruction is created, and each application of this element aplies the next row in that instruction.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:attribute name="instruction-ref" type="idref-type"/>
</xsd:complexType>

Whether the row count should be reset. Often pattern designers restart row numbering for a

    Row 1: Knit
    Row 2: Purl
    ...(some instructions here). Now do this:
    Row 1: k2tog, k to end 
    Row 2: p2tog, p to end
If this attribute isn't specified, the default is 'false'.

     Row 1: Knit
     Row 2: Purl
     ...(some instructions here). Now do this:

Complex Type ForEachRowInInstructionType

For each row in the referenced instruction, perform the child operations.
  For example, if the referenced instruction had three rows, the child operations would be

Complex Type UseNeedlesType
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
Make the needles specified by the children of this element the active
needles. This is different than the using-needle element, which only specifies what specific
operations to perform on an already active needle. This operation makes a global change to
the active needles.
Diagram
Used by
Element atomicBlockOperations/use-needles
Model needle+
Children needle
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
silent xsd:boolean optional 
When set to true, indicates that the operation should not be rendered but
is merely a directive to a computer program. If a cast-on element immediately follows a
this element and 'silent' is set to true, the intent is that these needles will be used
for the cast on, and a renderer may choose to mention which needles to cast onto as part
of rendering the cast on operation (rather than this one).
Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="UseNeedlesType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>Make the needles specified by the children of this element the active needles. This is different than the using-needle element, which only specifies what specific operations to perform on an already active needle. This operation makes a global change to the active needles.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:element maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1" name="needle" type="NeedleRefType"/>
  </xsd:sequence>
  <xsd:attribute name="silent" type="xsd:boolean">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>When set to true, indicates that the operation should not be rendered but is merely a directive to a computer program. If a cast-on element immediately follows a this element and 'silent' is set to true, the intent is that these needles will be used for the cast on, and a renderer may choose to mention which needles to cast onto as part of rendering the cast on operation (rather than this one).</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
</xsd:complexType>

Source
 
<xsd:complexType name="RepeatInstructionType">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>Repeat the child elements (block operations) as long as the until condition is not fulfilled. The condition will only be checked per full repetition of the instruction, not partially through an instruction repeat.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:choice>
      <xsd:element name="until-desired-length" type="EmptyType">
        <xsd:annotation>
          <xsd:documentation>Continue until the length desired is achieved. As this is subjective, the behavior for a validator is undefined.</xsd:documentation>
        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
      <xsd:element name="until-stitches-remain" type="xsd:short">

          <xsd:documentation>Continue until there are n number of active stitches, specified by the value of this element.</xsd:documentation>
        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
      <xsd:element name="until-stitches-remain-on-needles" type="UntilStitchesRemainOnNeedlesType">

        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
      <xsd:element name="until-measures" type="LengthType">
        <xsd:annotation>
          <xsd:documentation>Continue until the specified length has been knit (using this instruction repetition, not the total length of the work).</xsd:documentation>
        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
      <xsd:element name="additional-times" type="xsd:short">
        <xsd:annotation>
          <xsd:documentation>Continue until repeated the specified number of times.</xsd:documentation>
        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
      <xsd:element name="until-equals" type="UntilEqualsType">
        <xsd:annotation>
          <xsd:documentation>Continue until the children of this element equal each other.</xsd:documentation>
        </xsd:annotation>
      </xsd:element>
    </xsd:choice>
  </xsd:sequence>
  <xsd:attribute name="ref" type="idref-type">
    <xsd:annotation>
      <xsd:documentation>A reference to the instruction to repeat.</xsd:documentation>
    </xsd:annotation>
  </xsd:attribute>
</xsd:complexType>

<xsd:attribute name="yarn-ref" type="yarn-ref-type"/>
Attribute DecreaseType / @type
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
Indicates the type of decrease to perform. Note that the decrease names are defined assuming stitch mounts using Western knitting techniques.
Recognized decreases are:
ssk: slip-slip-knit (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, knit the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
k2tog: knit 2 together (knit 2 stitches together)
ssp: slip-slip-purl (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, purl the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
p2tog: purl 2 together (purl 2 stitches together)
skp: slip, knit, psso (slip 1 purlwise, knit 1, pass slipped stitch over knitted stitch)
k2tog-tbl: knit 2 together through their trailing loop
p2tog-tbl: purl 2 together through their trailing loop
Type restriction of xsd:string
Properties
content: simple
Facets
enumeration ssk
enumeration k2tog
enumeration ssp
enumeration p2tog
enumeration skp
enumeration k2tog-tbl
enumeration p2tog-tbl
Used by
Complex Type DecreaseType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="type">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>
      <![CDATA[
                Indicates the type of decrease to perform. Note that the decrease names are defined assuming stitch mounts using Western knitting techniques.
                Recognized decreases are:
                ssk: slip-slip-knit (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, knit the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
                k2tog: knit 2 together (knit 2 stitches together)
                ssp: slip-slip-purl (slip knitwise, slip knitwise, purl the 2 slipped stitches together through their now leading loops)
                p2tog: purl 2 together (purl 2 stitches together)
                skp: slip, knit, psso (slip 1 purlwise, knit 1, pass slipped stitch over knitted stitch)
                k2tog-tbl: knit 2 together through their trailing loop
                p2tog-tbl: purl 2 together through their trailing loop
                ]]>
    </xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:simpleType>
    <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
      <xsd:enumeration value="ssk"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="k2tog"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="ssp"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="p2tog"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="skp"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="k2tog-tbl"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="p2tog-tbl"/>
    </xsd:restriction>
  </xsd:simpleType>
</xsd:attribute>

Attribute IncreaseType / @yarn-ref
Namespace No namespace
Type yarn-ref-type
Type hierarchy
  • xsd:IDREF
    • idref-type
      • yarn-ref-type
Properties
content: simple
Used by
Complex Type IncreaseType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="yarn-ref" type="yarn-ref-type"/>
Attribute IncreaseType / @type
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
Indicates the type of increase to perform.
Recognized increases are:
m1: generic knit increase (implied if type is not specified)
m1p: generic purled increase
m1a: make 1 away (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing away)
m1t: make 1 towards (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing towards)
m1l: make one left (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1r: make one right (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, knit through trailing loop)
m1lp: make one left purled (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, purl through trailing loop)
m1rp: make one right purled (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, purl through trailing loop)
kll: knit left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, knit through trailing loop)
krl: knit right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, knit through leading loop)
pll: purl left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, purl through trailing loop)
prl: purl right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, purl through leading loop)
kfb: knit front and back (knit through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
pfb: purl front and back (purl through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
moss: knit through leading loop, then purl through leading loop of same st
decorative: knit into strand between sts
yo: bring working yarn in front and wrap it from bottom to top around the needle
Type restriction of xsd:string
Properties
use: optional
Facets
enumeration m1
enumeration m1p
enumeration m1a
enumeration m1t
enumeration m1l
enumeration m1r
enumeration m1lp
enumeration m1rp
enumeration kll
enumeration krl
enumeration pll
enumeration prl
enumeration kfb
enumeration pfb
enumeration moss
enumeration decorative
enumeration yo
Used by
Complex Type IncreaseType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="type" use="optional">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>
      <![CDATA[
                Indicates the type of increase to perform.
                Recognized increases are:
                m1: generic knit increase (implied if type is not specified)
                m1p: generic purled increase
                m1a: make 1 away (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing away)
                m1t: make 1 towards (put backwards loop on needle with tail facing towards)
                m1l: make one left (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, knit through trailing loop)
                m1r: make one right (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, knit through trailing loop)
                m1lp: make one left purled (insert left needle front-to-back between sts, purl through trailing loop)
                m1rp: make one right purled (insert left needle back-to-front between sts, purl through trailing loop)
                kll: knit left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, knit through trailing loop)
                krl: knit right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, knit through leading loop)
                pll: purl left loop (insert left needle into left loop of st two rows below last worked st, purl through trailing loop)
                prl: purl right loop (insert right needle into right loop of st below next st, put on left needle, purl through leading loop)
                kfb: knit front and back (knit through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
                pfb: purl front and back (purl through leading, then trailing loop of next st)
                moss: knit through leading loop, then purl through leading loop of same st
                decorative: knit into strand between sts
                yo: bring working yarn in front and wrap it from bottom to top around the needle
                ]]>
    </xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:simpleType>
    <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1p"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1a"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1t"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1l"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1r"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1lp"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="m1rp"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="kll"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="krl"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="pll"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="prl"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="kfb"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="pfb"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="moss"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="decorative"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="yo"/>
    </xsd:restriction>
  </xsd:simpleType>
</xsd:attribute>

Attribute RepeatType / @until
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
Specifies the terminating condition of this repeat. Values are:
end: repeat to the end (of the block inline operation)
before end: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is end
before gap: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a gap
before marker: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a marker
marker: repeat until a marker is encountered
times: a declared number of times (total, not additional)
Type restriction of xsd:string
Properties
use: required
Facets
enumeration end
enumeration before-end
enumeration before-gap
enumeration before-marker
enumeration marker
enumeration times
Used by
Complex Type RepeatType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="until" use="required">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>
      <![CDATA[Specifies the terminating condition of this repeat. Values are:
              end: repeat to the end (of the block inline operation)
              before end: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is end
              before gap: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a gap
              before marker: repeat until the number of sts specified by 'value' + current position is a marker
              marker: repeat until a marker is encountered
              times: a declared number of times (total, not additional)
              ]]>
    </xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:simpleType>
    <xsd:restriction base="xsd:string">
      <xsd:enumeration value="end"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="before-end"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="before-gap"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="before-marker"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="marker"/>
      <xsd:enumeration value="times"/>
    </xsd:restriction>
  </xsd:simpleType>
</xsd:attribute>

Attribute RowType / @number
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number,
it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any
existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row
numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form
of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction
element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should
assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number
attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).
Type list of xsd:short
Properties
content: simple
Used by
Complex Type RowType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="number">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>The row number(s). If this attribute takes the form of a single number, it must either be the number 1 or 1 plus the last row number. If the row number is 1, any existing local instructions (i.e. instructions that are only addressable by their row numbers) are discarded and can no longer be referenced. A list of row numbers (in the form of "1 3 5") is only allowed if this row is a child of an instruction element. Alternatively, omitting this attribute tells a pre-processor that it should assign the next logical row number to this attribute (unless the assign-row-number attribute is set to false, in which case it is left alone).</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:simpleType>
    <xsd:list itemType="xsd:short"/>
  </xsd:simpleType>
</xsd:attribute>

Attribute DeclareFlatKnittingType / @next-row-side
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
When working flat after working in the round, the next row can either

is required.

Attribute UseNeedlesType / @silent
Namespace No namespace
Annotations
 
When set to true, indicates that the operation should not be rendered but
is merely a directive to a computer program. If a cast-on element immediately follows a
this element and 'silent' is set to true, the intent is that these needles will be used
for the cast on, and a renderer may choose to mention which needles to cast onto as part
of rendering the cast on operation (rather than this one).
Type xsd:boolean
Properties
content: simple
Used by
Complex Type UseNeedlesType
Source
 
<xsd:attribute name="silent" type="xsd:boolean">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>When set to true, indicates that the operation should not be rendered but is merely a directive to a computer program. If a cast-on element immediately follows a this element and 'silent' is set to true, the intent is that these needles will be used for the cast on, and a renderer may choose to mention which needles to cast onto as part of rendering the cast on operation (rather than this one).</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
</xsd:attribute>

Element Group atomicInlineOperations
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
An atomic inline operation is a pattern direction which occurs inside a row
element. This includes operations such as knitting, purling, increases, decreases, and
binding off. It excludes elements which represent an aggregation of inline operations (e.g.
repeat, using-needle).
Diagram
Used by
Complex Types CompositeInlineOperationType, ForEachRowInInstructionType, FromStitchHolderType, InlineInstructionType, RepeatType, RowType, UsingNeedleType

Children apply-next-row, bind-off, bind-off-all, cross-stitches, decrease, designate-end-of-row, double-decrease, from-stitch-holder, increase, increase-into-next-stitch, inline-cast-on, inline-instruction-ref, inline-pick-up-stitches, knit, no-stitch, pass-previous-stitch-over, place-marker, purl, remove-marker, slip, slip-to-stitch-holder, turn, work-even
Source

Element Group compositeInlineOperations
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
A composite inline operation groups together atomic inline operations
within the context of a row. The meaning of the operation applies to all of its child
elements.

Element Group atomicBlockOperations
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
An atomic block operation is a pattern direction which occurs outside of a
row element. This group includes operations such as casting on, joining stitches in the
round, and grafting. It excludes elements which represent an aggregation of block operations
(e.g. instruction, instruction-group, section).

Attribute Group labelAttrs
Namespace http://www.knitml.com/schema/pattern
Annotations
 
A label attribute provides a means by which to assign text to different
operations. The 'message-key' attribute is a key which is resolvable to a value specific to
the user's language. The 'label' attribute is the literal value of the label written in the
pattern's original language. Both can be provided.
Diagram
Used by
Complex Types InlineInstructionType, InstructionGroupType, InstructionType, LabelNeedleType, MergedInstructionType, MessageType
Attributes
QName Type Fixed Default Use Annotation
label xsd:string optional
message-key message-key-type optional
Source
 
<xsd:attributeGroup name="labelAttrs">
  <xsd:annotation>
    <xsd:documentation>A label attribute provides a means by which to assign text to different operations. The 'message-key' attribute is a key which is resolvable to a value specific to the user's language. The 'label' attribute is the literal value of the label written in the pattern's original language. Both can be provided.</xsd:documentation>
  </xsd:annotation>
  <xsd:attribute name="message-key" type="message-key-type"/>
  <xsd:attribute name="label" type="xsd:string"/>
</xsd:attributeGroup>
